div.p: 1. VI: After hearing George read this morning, I took up this book again, and finished writing page 329. It was all that I could accomplish before Breakfast, and I find the difficulty of writing yet very great— After Breakfast Mrs Adams wrote as I dictated, a Letter to the Secretary of the Treasury, concerning the affair of Mr M’Call’s Bills on account of the Navy Department, and a Letter to Mr Isaac Smith of Boston, in answer to that which he had written me by the late Mr Cary. I had a second visit from the inventing geniuses Mr Service and Mr Studley— They now brought out three printed Projects 1. Prospectus of a Bill, intended to be submitted to Parliament, for a National Institution, to ameliorate the Condition of the Poor; abolish the Poor Rates, &c. &c. 2. Prospectus for the Establishment of a Coal light Company. 3. The Dry Rot in Buildings, effectually cured, and its return prevented— And eight written proposals for other improvements moral, political and physical. 1. A new and improved system for preparing Flax and Hemp. 2. A new method for bleaching Cotton Canvas and all vegetable substance 3. Method for preparing and using Gas, and all its products. 4. Improved wind power for driving Machenery. 5. New and improved Paper Mill. 6. New and improved Ordnance for Sea and Land Service. 7. Proposals for introducing a new System of Education. 8. Proposals for working Mines in America— I observed to them that the Iron pavement was omitted. They said that they had not put that down, and there were many others which if they once got settled in America, and found encouragement, they should be able to introduce, to the great benefit of the Country. I asked them if they proposed to take out a patent for their system of Education?— No— They had put down, improvements of various kinds, which it would be in their power to introduce, but they did not expect patents for them all.— They kept me nearly two hours, explaining what they did not themselves understand, repeating the question whether I thought the gas-lights, and the flax-bleaching, and the iron-pavement would be useful in America. I had answered all these questions when they were here before, and repeated the promise that when they were ready to go, I would give them Letters to some of my friends who might afford them assistance in obtaining their Patents, or even an alteration of the Patent-Law, so that Patents might be taken out by them for inventions already known here— At length they let out the secret of all their applications to me, by hinting in answer to my enquiries when they intended to go, that they should go very shortly, though they supposed the Government of this Country would hinder them if they could. I now saw what they were seeking, and that they were mechanics of the Class who are not allowed by Law to leave this Country.— That they had been baiting for some aid or protection from me to smuggle them out, and that their inventions were all mere pretences— I determined to have nothing to do with them, and waited with what Patience I could until they went away— In the Evening we finished reading Miss Edgeworth’s Almeria.

2. VI:15. Heard George read, and wrote again about half a page before Breakfast— Went into London; called at Lord Castlereagh’s house, at the corner of St. James’s Square, and left a Card. He returned from Paris, and arrived in London last Wednesday. When I got to the Office I found there an official Note from him, dated 29. November stating that the Lord Mayor of London had made a Representation to the home department that a number of American Seamen were wandering about the Streets in a most wretched and distressed Condition, and that several of them were supported at the Police Establishments and Hospitals of the City at a considerable expence. He therefore requires me to take measures for sending these persons to their native Country. I directed Mr Grubb to make a Copy of this Note, and send it to Mr Beasley. It requires a very deliberate answer— There was a Note also from Mr Lullin of the Alien Office, stating by way of explanation, that foreigners are still obliged to take out Passports from that Office, and that the circular from the foreign Office, of the 23d: of September, only meant that Passports would be granted at the alien-office to foreigners, upon documents, other than the Passports of their own Ministers— I called at the foreign Office and enquired for Mr Morier— They informed me that he no longer belonged to the Office; Mr Cook who had been the Under Secretary of State before him, having resumed the place. I then asked for Mr Hamilton and saw him. I shewed him the Note I had just received from Lord Castlereagh, and told him that as it related to business within the Consular Department, the arrangements must of course be made by the Consul lately arrived, and that he was waiting for his exequatur— Mr Hamilton enquired of a Clerk if it was ready. It was gone for the Prince’s Signature, but had not been returned— Mr Hamilton said the Note itself was a circular; the Lord Mayor having sent a Representation of the same kind respecting the Seamen of several foreign Nations, although the name only of one individual belonging to each of them had been reported— I mentioned the Note from Mr Lullin of the Alien-Office, and what Mr Maury had lately written me from Liverpool. I shewed him the Circular from Lord Bathurst which referred to one from Lord Castlereagh of 15 May last— This I had never seen, as it had been sent to the foreign Ministers, ten days before my arrival in London. I asked him if he could let me have a copy of it. He sent for the Book, and read me the Note— It was a notification that the Government had determined to grant Passports at the Alien-Office, only to foreigners who should produce Passports from the Ministers of their own Country at this Court. Hamilton said it was a regulation founded upon the Act of Parliament, and had been made chiefly to prevent Frenchmen from going and coming between this Country and France, unless they were recognized by the French Ambassador— This regulation was now revoked, but the Act of Parliament itself, required that Aliens should take Passports at the Alien Office, and that could be repealed only by the Authority of Parliament. I told him it was very inconvenient to Americans—particularly to those who were engaged in commercial affairs and went from Liverpool, and that was the place where perhaps nine tenths of all Americans in England arrived at, and sailed from— He said it was probable the restriction would not be continued beyond the next Session of Parliament— I spoke of the subjects concerning which Mr English had written to me, from Dublin— The Irish Post-Office-Bill, and the regulation by which American Vessels are allowed to take out from Ireland only one Passenger, for every five tons, while British vessels are permitted to take a passenger for every two tons. The Post-Office Bill compels all Persons writing Letters, and sending them by any other conveyance than the British Packets, between America and Ireland, to pay Postage for them— I told him this was levying a tax upon people in America for having correspondents in Ireland. Mr English also had complained that it was both a tax and a restriction upon his official correspondence with the Government of the United States— But the Post-master at Dublin had removed that difficulty for the present, by suspending the application of the Law to his official Correspondence— Mr Hamilton said that as to private Correspondence, the Law was no more than what was generally practiced by other Governments— That in France and Germany private travellers were not allowed to carry Letters—that he himself had had Letters taken from him at the gates of Vienna, and put into the Post-Office— I said I had never known of any such regulation upon the Continent of Europe; but if there was, the principle might be different, where Letters travelled by land, and passed through the Territory— Here, there was no carriage by land within the Country— It was an impediment to the freedom of intercourse between the Countries, and tended to produce a counter-tax of the same kind, in America, upon British Letters. He said, that might indeed happen, but it was no more a restriction upon intercourse than duties upon the importation upon merchandize— I finally told him I was aware it was a thing upon which I could make no formal and official remonstrance; but that it was a great inconvenience to the merchants, and could be of very little profit to the revenue— A Law of the same kind with respect to Great Britain had
been repealed or suffered to expire since I arrived in this Country, and I hoped they would let the Irish Ship-Letter-Act have the same fate.— He said that as to the Packet, he did not think there was any necessity for keeping it up at-all in time of Peace, as the intercourse by merchant vessels was so easy and so frequent. I agreed in this opinion, and said I supposed the Packets were kept up, chiefly for their intercourse with their own Colonies.— With regard to the distinction made between American, and British vessels, in the number of Passengers which they are permitted to carry, he said he thought with me, that it was not consistent with the Commercial Convention, concluded last July— He did not know upon what principle the distinction was made; but he took a minute of it, and promised to enquire into it, and have it remedied if he could— On returning to my own Office, I found a Letter directed to me, which upon reading I perceived was not to me— But as it was from Studley the inventor, I concluded he had been writing two Letters, one of which was for me, and that he had superscribed to me the wrong one. There was nothing in the one that I received, indicating for whom it was intended; but Mr Grubb thought he knew— It contained however one piece of information, which they had not given me yesterday, and differing from what they had told me before—namely, that young Service would probably not go to America, having been offered the place of Steward to a Nobleman.— I desired Mr Grubb to send back this Letter, and inform Studley of his mistake— I added that I thought Mr West had acted improperly in recommending these persons to me to assist them in the project of going to America, when he knew they were not allowed by law to quit the Country— It was about six O’Clock when I reached home— Walked from the Kensington Turnpike to the Corner of Boston-Lane, Brentford; about five miles— I found my Sons John and Charles at home, but they returned after dinner to School.

3. VI:30. George’s reading and half a page again of this Journal occupied me this morning until breakfast time. We all went to Church and heard the whole service performed for Advent Sunday by Mr Lewis— His Sermon was from Luke Chap. X. v. 37. upon the Story of the good Samaritan— I believe it is impossible to make a bad Sermon upon that Subject. It inspires dulness itself. Mr Lewis is a very indifferent preacher; but there is much inequality in his discourses, and this was one of his best— After Church I walked from Ealing to Gunnersbury, and through Brentford home— Mrs Adams paid a visit to the Miss Nicholas’s, and received visits from Major and Mrs Morison, and Miss Carnell, and from Mrs Von Harten, who was a daughter of Mr Burr of Fairfield in Connecticut— She made a runaway match from a Boarding school at New-York with an Englishman named Jenkins by whom she had her two daughters— After his death she married Mr Von Harten, by whom she has no children— But she wishes them to take his name, taking no satisfaction in the remembrance of her former husband— Two of George’s Schoolmates, Patch and Hastie dined with us. Patch is the Son of an Officer in the East-India Service, and was born in India. The Evening was clear and cold, and I was looking for the New Moon; but could not discover it, although this is the third day since the change, and we had seen the old one, the last day but one of its last quarter— Mrs Adams received a Letter from Mr Grubb, at Mortlake, to recommend three female Servants instead of those who are to leave us. Mrs Adams determined to go to London, to see them on Tuesday.

4. VI:15. By writing at the rate of half a page a day, I should never be able to retrieve the arrears of my Journal; from this time forward therefore I have resolved if I can accomplish it, to write at least a page on the average every day, until they shall be brought up. I accordingly wrote this day an entire page.— A Mr Wolford came here; lately arrived from Philadelphia. He is an Englishman, by Birth, and has relations in this neighbourhood; but is settled in America, and intends to return there. He brought with him several Prints, of the Collection, now publishing by Mr Delaplaine— Among them one, of Commodore Perry’s victory on Lake Erie; which with Portraits of President Washington from Houdon’s bust, of Mr Jay, Mr King, R. Fulton and De Witt Clinton, I took of him. He had also those of President Madison. Dr Rush, General Harrison, and a Dr Wilson, but so badly executed that I declined taking them. My wife finished writing for me the Letter to my Mother which she had begun, last Friday; and in the Evening she and George read to me Miss Edgeworths affecting Tale of the Dun— In my walk round before dinner through Ealing, Acton & Gunnersbury I first saw the Moon since the change— She sat about five O’Clock, and before dark— I cannot comprehend why this luminary should be visible so much nearer to the change, before, than after it.

5. VI:15. I am engaged in hearing George read until full day-light; and from that time until breakfast, assiduous at the Journal. The morning school hour is already transferred from seven O’Clock to half past seven, and previous to the vacation will be protracted until eight— I went into Town with Mrs Adams, and at the Office she saw the three servant women, recommended by Mrs Grubb’s Sister, Mrs Poole, of Mortlake— There was at the Office a Mr Denniston, late a Lieutenant Colonel in the army of the United States. He came for a Passport which was given him, as he produced his Commission and a Passport from the Secretary of State. He is an Irishman born, and in the Irish insurrection of 1798 was in arms against the British Government. He at that time escaped, and went to America, where he settled and has been naturalized. In the late War he bore the Commission of a Lieutenant Coll.— He has an Estate in Ireland, and is very desirous of going there. He asked my advice, whether I thought it safe for him, to go, and whether I could assist him to obtain from this Government an assurance that he would not be molested. I told him that as to the safety of the measure, he must be a better judge of that than I could be. I certainly could not advise him to it— I could and would if he desired it, mention his name and case to Lord Castlereagh, and ask the permission for him to go to Ireland with the pledge that he should not be prosecuted; but he must be aware, that if the disposition to prosecute him existed, this would necessarily disclose the fact of his being here, and expose him to the very danger he wished to avoid. He said he had in fact lately been in Ireland, and had left it under the apprehension of a prosecution; but all the magistrates of the County where he had belonged, and where he had taken part in the Insurrection, were now willing to recommend him to the Government for an exemption from the Proscription. Even the Officer who had commanded the kings troops in an action which took place in 1798. and who had then reported him Denniston, as having commanded the Insurgents, was now satisfied that he had then been misinformed, and willing to join in the recommendation— I told him that an application through those channels, would have a much better prospect of success than through me; particularly as his Commission in the late American Army, if known, would have no tendency to encourage in Lord Castlereagh an oblivious disposition of what had occurred in 1798. Coll: Denniston finally concurred in this opinion, and said he would prefer not to incur the risk, of what might be the consequence of an application from me— I had also a visit from Mr Austen of Ramsgate; the Son of the person who applied to me last Summer for the Consular Agency at that place, and who brought a Letter of recommendation from Mr Goulburn. The object of his present visit is the same; and he requested me to mention his name to Coll: Aspinwall, whom he had however already seen— Chitty the Taylor called and took some orders— Mr Grubb had not prepared the despatches I had sent him; which must wait until Saturday before they can be sent to Liverpool.— Mr Grubb sent back to Mr Studley the Letter which he had directed by mistake to me last Saturday,—and this day I found at the Office the Letter which Studley had written to me— He refers me to several persons for his characters, and informs me that it is intended, to take Patents in America, for several Inventions not mentioned in the list delivered to me last Friday, as soon as the Laws in that Country are amended; and to proceed there without delay— We returned home about six in the Evening— It rained almost the whole day, and the roads were very heavy— After dinner we began Miss Edgeworth’s Manoeuvering.

6. VI:30. The writing before breakfast becomes tolerably regular, and after it, my wife writes for me— She wrote this day, Letters to Mr Maury at Liverpool, to Mr Thomas English who before the late War, was Consul of the United States at Dublin, and from whom, I received a Letter on the 9th: of last Month, written in the Consular capacity— It had hitherto remained unanswered. I believe he assumes the character on the strength of his old Commission, but I have written to enquire. She wrote also to Mr Everett at the Hague; in answer to four Letters received from him since I wrote him last— I walked before dinner to the Turnpike on the road to Windsor. Met Dr Cook on Boston Terrace at Brentford. He looked at my eye, and enquired whether I now used any lotion for it— I told him that I washed it every morning with Brandy and water. He advised me to add vinegar to the wash— A table-spoonful and tea-spoonful of vinegar, and same quantity of brandy to a pint of cold Springwater— I had been several days without receiving the usual budget of Letters— This day Mr Grubb sent me out one from a Mr Gustavus Hippisley, enclosing one from Captain Trenchard for the United States Navy. Mr Hippisley supposes Captain Trenchard to be a kinsman of his and writes to ascertain the fact, requesting me to forward his Letter. I also received a Letter from Mr Lock, the man who sent me the account of £15:8 for custom-house charges upon my baggage from Russia— He refused to take the £10:5 I had left with Mr Grubb to pay him, and calls again for the payment of the whole bill—insisting that five guineas is a very moderate charge for his agency, (which was nothing) to a person of my rank and consequence. There were also two Letters that came from Liverpool; one directed to Mr Lawrence the Secretary of Legation
at Stockholm, and the other to John Adams Smith, Secretary to the Legation of the United States at the Court of Great-Britain. I had learnt by the last Letter which I received from my brother, that J. A. Smith had obtained this appointment; and have been some time expecting his arrival. This Letter is directed in his own hand-writing.

7. VI. This day I have closed my Journal for the Month of October, still leaving 37 days of arrears to redeem; which will take me longer than I had expected, as I find I have much more to write. I enclosed to Mr Grubb the Letters yesterday written, to be copied and forwarded— Prepared a Note, in answer to that received on the 2d: instant from Lord Castlereagh, respecting the Sailors; and began a Letter to Mr Russell at Stockholm; but Mrs Adams being unwell, we were obliged to leave it unfinished— We received Letters from our Sons John and Charles, announcing that the Vacation at Ealing School is to commence on the 21st: instant— These Letters are written by all the boys, to their Parents and Relations, serving at once as hints that they may be sent for, and as samples of the hand writing of the boys, to shew their improvement— Took a walk with George before dinner to Isleworth; our walk was of about six miles— There was a prospect of rain when we went out; and a frost which had almost dried the roads, before we got home. This Evening I had Letters from Mr Grubb—from Messrs: Baring Brothers and Co.—from Mr Maury, and from Mr J. A. Smith my nephew and Secretary of Legation, who arrived on the 4th: instant, at Liverpool, after a passage of twenty-seven days from New-York— He was to leave Liverpool yesterday and will probably reach London to-morrow. Mr Maury is excessively troubled with destitute Sailors, and greatly concerned about the repayment of his advances for their support, and to pay for their passages to the United States. He has written to the Secretary of State concerning it as I advised him, and requests me to write to the Government also in support of his claims for reimbursement— The Baring’s inform me that they have received a remittance of £4500 from the Commissioners of the Public Buildings at Washington, to be subject of the drafts authorised by them of Mr Richard M’Call, Consul of the United States at Barcelona— And Messrs: Baring enquire of me, whether they may apply this sum to the payment in part of what they have assumed, for the discharge of Mr M’Call’s Bills upon the Glennie’s on account of the Navy Department— This I think might be inconvenient.— Mr Grubb mentions having settled the Account for the freight of our baggage from St. Petersburg— Also that he has a Letter from Mr Shaw of S. Carolina, dated yesterday at Gosport by distress of Weather— The Newspapers are full of damage and shipwrecks by gales of wind the last three or four days.

8. VI:15. I see the Planets Venus and Jupiter every clear morning, and this day they were within five minutes distance of each other. The rapidity of the motion of Venus and the slowness of that of Jupiter, are marked by their relative position and apparent distance from Antares which is likewise visible and not distant from them— The change in the position of Venus, is already very considerable since the first morning when I saw her, which was the 29th ulto.— Mrs Adams was quite sick all day and confined to her bed until near dinner time— As she could not write for me, I wrote a page and half of this Journal, and answered the Letter yesterday received from the Brothers Baring— I requested them to keep the remittance received from the Commissioners of the Public Buildings upon a distinct Account, and not to apply it to the discharge of Mr M’Call’s Bills, for accounts of the Navy Department, unless with the assent. The two eldest Miss Nicholas’s called to visit Mrs Adams, but she could not see them. They came to invite us to attend the exhibitions at the school next week; on Monday at Noon a fencing match, at which Mr Barberi is to exhibit the improvement of his pupils— On that Tuesday Evening, two Lectures upon Astronomy, Optics and Vision, by an itinerant Professor; and on Wednesday Evening, some slight of hand tricks with Cards, Cups and Balls, &c.— George is to have a party of his school-fellows to dinner to-morrow, and Mrs: Adams invited the Miss Nicholas’s to come and spend the Evening here— Mr Frederick Pursh came to visit me— He is a Native of Siberia; was educated in Saxony, and has been many years settled in the United-Sates, of which he is a naturalized citizen. He is a man of Science, and about two years since came to England where he published a work entitled Flora Americae Septentrionalis, in two Volumes. He now wishes to return to New-York, where he has in partnership with another person some agricultural Establishment; and as he says, considerable property— But he is embarrassed in his finances, and wants a loan of twenty pounds Sterling to enable him to take passage. I told him I should be glad to give him any assistance in my power, but he was a total Stranger to me— I had nothing
to trust to but his own Story, and I had more than once suffered loss by lending money to persons in similar Circumstances, who upon their arrival in America forgot their debts to me— He shewed me the record of his naturalization, and a Letter from the keeper of the Museum of Natural History at Paris, thanking him for the present of a Copy of his Flora of North America. I asked him, whether, as he had property at New-York, he could not procure his passage upon credit, with a Captain who would agree to receive his pay there. He said his passage would be partly upon credit— But he was with his wife and must raise fifty pounds to lay in their Stores and for the passage— He asked me only for twenty— I asked him if he could not name to me any person who would be responsible to me for the repayment of the money— He said he thought Sir Joseph Banks would. Sir Joseph himself had been already so kind to him in the same way, that he was ashamed to ask him for any further loan— He had however ordered seeds and plants to be sent to him from America to the amount of the debt and which would make the repayment of it very easy— I told him that was sufficient— If he would bring me a line from Sir Joseph Banks, pledging himself for the reimbursement of the money, I would lend him the twenty pounds, and take his promissory Note for it— Mrs Adams sent Pio this morning into London; Mr Grubb sent out by him a Book entitled “the Philosophy of Sense; or Book of Nature”; &c a long title—by John Stewart, the Traveller. From the Era of its own Publication, in the 7000th: Year of Astronomical History, taken from the Chinese Tables—London printed for the author. 4. Cockspur Street. It is dedicated to the United States of America, and appears to be the production of a Crazy Person— It was sent to the Office by the two-penny Post, accompanied by a Note, with the Authors respectful Compliments to me, and information that he has as many Vols at my Service, as I may require to send to my friends in America— As upon opening the Book I found it contained a compound of nonsense, galimatias, and vulgar abuse upon the people of America, I shall think it unnecessary to take any Notice of the Authors Present or of his offer— I walked before dinner to Hanwell and Ealing; and in the Evening we finished reading Miss Edgeworth’s Manoeuvering— This is the third and last Volume of her first set of Tales of fashionable life.— There is another set of three Volumes, more recently published, and said to be yet better. There is no modern English Novel writer, whom I think comparable to Miss Edgeworth— These Tales are all interesting, although the moral of no one of them is for my use— So long as I am blest with eyes and hands, and health I shall never know the evil, nor need a remedy for ennui. The Passion for fashionable Society, the aversion to paying just debts, and manoeuvering are all so foreign to every feeling and every habit of mine, that I have scarcely an admonition to take from these Volumes— I could gather more profitable instruction from Waverley— But there is more of Nature in Miss Edgeworth’s characters and incidents— More of real life, and less of Romance. The most indifferent of these Tales, is Madame de Fleury, the chief object of which seems to be to represent in the most exalted light, the character of french emigrants— As worthless a Class of People in reality as any equal number of their fellow creatures who have crawled through life since their emigration began— And a class of People, now as mischievous as they have always been contemptible. There are doubtless exceptions— But the moral of a novel should not be founded upon exceptions— The general moral deducible from Madame de Fleury is good; but commonplace— Charity and kindness to the poor— The return of Gratitude from the Poor, is also a common-place of all movels; though not so in real life— Charity to the Poor is a duty which ought not to rest upon interested motives, or the expectation of returns.

9. VI:15. I had intended not to go into London, until next Tuesday, but the expectation of meeting Mr J. A. Smith there, and several Letters which I received this morning induced me to change this determination. I could therefore only write half a page of my Journal. The Letters were three enclosures from Mr Grubb— The first a packet from Messrs: Alexander Glennie, Son and Co. with a Despatch from the American Department of State—a Letter from Mr Stephen Pleasonton, a Clerk in that Department, written in the absence, but by the order of Mr Monroe, instructing me to apply to the British Government, for restitution or indemnity, to Mr Karthaus a Citizen of the United States for the capture of a Vessel called the Baltimore, at St. Andero within the territorial Jurisdiction of Spain, in the year 1812. by boats from British Ships of War, in that harbour— The application is to be made to the British Government, on account of the unsettled state of our political relations with Spain. There is a Protest signed by the Captain and Mate of the Baltimore; a statement by Mr Karthaus of the value of the vessel and Cargo, with his Affidavit before a Notary Public that they were his property—the sentence of condemnation by the Court of Admiralty at London, and a written opinion of Mr W. Pinkney as Counsel to Mr Karthaus, recommending an application to the British Government for redress.— The Letter from Messrs: Glennie, requests my immediate attention to this affair, and proposes that Mr Karthaus should call upon me to take my advice concerning it— The second and third enclosures were packets
from Mr Beasley— One containing a long Letter from him on the subject of the Sailors, in reference to the Note from Lord Castlereagh, of which I sent him some days ago a copy— The facts stated and the suggestions contained in his Letter, made it necessary for me to have some Conversation with him, and to postpone the answer to Lord Castlereagh’s Note— The answer itself must also be a different one, from that which I had prepared— The other enclosed a Letter to Mr Beasley from Mr Cobbett, the Editor of the Political Register— It refers him to a plan which Cobbett has formed of sending out a person to New-York, to establish a regular literary communication between the United States and this Country; the details of which plan, he says are published in this day’s Register. But he says that he and his Son, intend at the same time to send out some works, of which they wish to have Copy-rights in America; and he asks two questions with regard to the Law of the United States, concerning copy-rights.— Mr Beasley being unable to answer these questions asks me to give him the information requested— I went into Town, with the view of meeting Mr J. A. Smith— Mr Grubb said a Gentleman had called about half an hour before I arrived— He had a parcel of American Newspapers for me; but had neither mentioned his name nor where he lodged. He had taken the direction of my house at Ealing, and said he would come out to morrow Morning— Mr Grubb wrote by my direction to Mr Beasley, mentioning that I would call upon him at his house in Harley-Street, at Noon on Tuesday; or if that should not suit his convenience requesting him to call at my Office in Charles Street at two O’Clock the same day—or if not, to let me know when and where he could see me. Mr J. C. Gray called at the Office— He has been on a tour into the Country since he was here before, and has just returned— He said that Mr Very had called at his lodgings before he left London; but he was out and did not see him— He had left word however that I had lent him money; which he Gray would repay me— I told him I had not meant to call upon him for the repayment, and Very had given me a draft upon his own father at Salem— Mr Gray proposes to go shortly to France, and asked me for advice, concerning his travels, which I accordingly gave him.— The weather being fine, I ordered the Carriage to come to the Office at four O’Clock— I left it myself at three with directions, that the Coachman should follow and overtake me on the Brentford Road— He did overtake me at the Corner of the Street from Brentford; but having walked thus far, I chose to complete the walk home, and came from the Office to my house, nine miles and a few rods, in precisely two hours and a half— The weather, and roads were as favourable for walking as possible— I found George’s Company all assembled— His Schoolmates Buttanshaw, Chambré, Flexnay, Hamilton, Jackson, Patch, Sheaffe, Turner, & Wright dined and spent the Evening with us— The four Miss Nicholas’s came to tea, and we had music and singing by the two eldest but Mrs Adams, who had been very unwell the whole day, found herself immediately after dinner so ill that she was obliged to quit the drawing-room, and retire to bed. The boys had leave to stay till ten O’Clock, but it was past eleven before the party broke up, and we sent them all back to school together, except Wright, whose Uncle, Sir James Wright, lives in our neighbourhood, and sent for him soon after ten— Sir James is the Son, of the last Royal Governor of Georgia; and was born in America— Our sons John and Charles stay this Night at home.

10. VIII. Mrs: Adams was much better this day, but still very weak, and unable to go out— I went to Church with all the boys The whole service was performed by Mr Lewis, whose discourse had so little interest that it has left no recollections. As I expected Mr J. A. Smith, I returned home, immediately after Church. I had a visit from Mr Gray, and old Gentleman, whom we have met at Dr Nicholas’s at dinner, and who resides in our neighbourhood. He apologized for Mrs Gray’s not being with him to visit Mrs Adams; but she was confined to the house by illness— Mr Smith came out about four O’Clock. He brought me a bundle of Newspapers from the Government, but not one line of despatches. He had several Letters for the family,—two for me from my Mother, dated 30 Septr: and 23. Octr: and one from my father of 22 Octr.— The last from my Mother encloses copies of two Letters of Recommendation of Mr J. A. Smith, for the Office of Secretary to this Legation— One from Governor Tompkins of New-York to President Madison, and the other from Judge W. P. Van Ness to Mr J. P. Van Ness of Washington— Smith had written also to me to ask my Recommendation which I had declined to give, because I had already recommended Mr A. H. Everett, and because I do not think that an American Secretary of Legation ought to be the nephew of the Minister at the same Court— As however the President has thought fit to appoint him, it becomes me to respect his decision— We had two of our Son John’s Classmates at school, to dine with us, Baker and Gatty— John and Charles returned with them to school after dinner.

11. VI—45. I had leisure time this day, only to write half a page of my Journal— We were all prepared to go the School to see the fencing Match, when Mr Frederick Pursh came in, and brought me a Letter from Sir Joseph Banks— It speaks in high
terms of Mr Pursh’s skill as a Botanist—of his work, the Flora Americae Septentrionalis, and of his abilities to add still further to the knowledge of the Natural History of that Country— He adds that in consideration of his Botanical knowledge, and with the view to enable him to return to America, and further improve the Science, he, Sir Joseph had at different times lent him money, and shall consider it well bestowed, although he should never receive any part of it again, if Mr Pursh should resume his Studies— I observed to Mr Pursh that this Letter was not precisely what he had led me to expect Sir Joseph Banks would give him— It neither assured me of the repayment by him of any money that I might lend him, nor engaged the writer to pay it in case of his default. He said it was very true; and he had noticed it when Sir Joseph shewed him the Letter, which he did before closing it— But he had not had courage to ask him to alter it— I then told him it should suffice— I would lend him the twenty Pounds— He said he should ask my acceptance of a Copy of his work— I told him I would wish pleasure take a Copy; but I must deduct the price of it from the amount of his Note— He said its cost was 2 1/2 guineas— I therefore lent him twenty Pounds, and took his promissory note in duplicates, for seventy five dollars— I then went with Mrs Adams and Mr Smith to Dr Nicholas’s School, to the fencing match— We were belated and found it half over— We found our Sons John & Charles in the midst of an Assaut— Excepting our Sons, Barberi has only four pupils at the school—Daniell, Patch, Sheaffe and Watson. They all displayed their improvements, by fencing with Barberi and with each other. After it was over, we went into the drawing room, and heard Mr Gini and Miss Nicholas on the Piano, with singing— Gini is the music Master of the Young Ladies— An Italian, and an excellent singer.— We returned home and shortly afterwards I took a walk with Mr Smith to Gunnersbury, returning by the way of Brentford— At seven in the Evening we went again to the School, and heard a Lecture upon Astronomy, Light, and Optics, by a Mr Garrett— It was not very amusing, and the Professor however skilled in Natural History, was not very well grounded in the Language— His pronunciation was so bad, that one could scarcely hear it and refrain from laughing— The boys especially shewed some manifestations of being disorderly— It finished between nine and ten, and we immediately came home. Received a packet from Mr Grubb, enclosing Letters from Messrs: Willink’s & Van Staphorsts, from Mr Beasley and from a Mr Collier— The Bankers at Amsterdam reply to my Letter of 27. ulto:—they have received their authority to draw upon the Baring’s, and have commenced drawing— Mr Beasley promises to call at my Office at half past two O’Clock to-morrow; and Mr Collier, a person wholly unknown to me sends me a law question, and will send to my Office for the Answer to it to-morrow— The question is whether in America, the husband of a married woman, can receive a legacy devised to her, by a written authority, without a personal examination of the wife before a Court of equity, where she should declare her consent, or without the husband’s making a settlement upon her. One of these alternatives it states to be indispensable in England— Mr Smith says they are not so in the State of New-York, where the husband and wife in this case resided.

12. VI:30. Only half a page of Journal again this morning— I went into London this morning with Mr J. A. Smith— Since his arrival, it has become necessary for me to part with Mr Grubb, whom I engaged only by the week, until the Secretary of Legation should come. It is hard upon Grubb, and comes with double severity at this Season of the year— I have determined to keep him until the close of the year, to finish the business now on hand, and to give time to Mr Smith to get settled in the Office and acquainted with the course of business. There was a person called, coming from Mr Collier for an answer to his question— I told him that our Laws in America, were different in the different States of the Union; but that in Massachusetts, of which I was a Citizen, and as I was informed in New-York, where he said the parties interested in his question resided, the husband might receive a Legacy bequeathed to his wife, upon a written Letter of Attorney duly authenticated before a magistrate, without personal examination of the wife by a Court of equity— The magistrate taking the acknowledgment of the Power being supposed competent to make such examination, and to have made it— I offered to give this answer in writing, if Mr Collier desired it— The person who came said he believed it would not be necessary; but if it should Mr Collier would send again to request it. Mr Grubb wrote for me an answer to the Letter of Messrs. Glennie received last Saturday, and I propose to see Mr Karthaus upon his business, whenever it may suit his convenience— Mr Beasley came at half past two. He had made some Statements in his last Letter to me concerning the Sailors, upon which I was desirous of ascertaining the State of the Evidence. He had mentioned that many of the destitute American Seamen now applying for support and to be sent home, were men lately discharged from the British Naval service, and who had been impressed into it. And that there were others, entitled to small Pensions, which they were compelled to sell for two or three years purchase when
they returned to the United States. He had suggested the idea of an application to the British Government, to suit the cases of these men; and I myself think it perfectly proper— He said he could furnish me lists of the destitute Seamen discharged from the British Navy, that he had sent to America, and of those to whom he had delivered certificates to enable them to sell their Pensions. He is to write to me again upon the Subject— I gave him verbal answers to the two questions in Mr Cobbett’s Letter, respecting Copy-Rights, by the Laws of the United States. Cobbett himself is not a Citizen of the United States; but his Son is— His questions are whether he or his Son could have copy-rights taken out, in their names, by an Agent in America, for works, written by them in this Country. Cobbett wrote that he had only the Act of Congress respecting Copy-Rights, that is in the first Volume of the Laws of the United States— He was informed there was a subsequent Law, but he knew not what it was— I took the Volume of the Laws, containing the Supplementary Act, with me to Town, and directed Mr Grubb to make a Copy of the Act, and send it to Mr Beasley.— It has no reference however to Mr Cobbett’s questions. I answered them—that the Son as a Citizen of the United States, might have a copy-right taken out in his name, as author of works written by him in England, and the agent, duly authorized, would be competent to take out the copy-right— That the father could not have one taken out in his name, as author of works written by him here; but his agent might take one out in his own name, as proprietor of the works—and to make him the proprietor would be merely a matter of arrangement between Cobbett and him— Mr Beasley asked me to send him back Cobbett’s Letter, which I promised— I ordered the Carriage, when it came to the Office at three, to take Mr J. A. Smith to his lodgings in Bridge-Street, at Walker’s Hotel, and then without coming back for me to go homeward’s through Hyde Park, and the Brentford road until it should overtake me— Just as Mr Smith had left the Office, Mr George Joy came in, and engaged me in Conversation, until Mr Grubb gave me two or three hints that my Carriage would get to Hyde-Park before me, and that I should have to walk the whole way home— I left the Office however about four, and Mr Joy walked with me as far as Hyde Park corner— He was very urgent in persuading me, to consult Sir William Adams, the most fashionable oculist of the present time, about my eyes. But as I know that oculists can do me no good, I am not very eager to consult them— Mr Joy, who has had these seven years a Commission of Consul of the United States at Rotterdam without ever going there, feels a strong anxiety respecting the compensation of American Consuls for which he thinks it indispensable that provision should be made. I gave him no hopes that a majority of both houses of Congress, would be of his opinion— He told me that General Lyman had lived here as an American Consul, ought to live; but that he had made out accounts of five or six pounds for cases when his legal fees did not amount to fifteen shillings; and he had been informed as of a matter of notoriety that Asbury Dickins, sold Protections for Sailors as Americans, at a guinea a piece to any body that would pay so much for them— We parted at Hyde Park Corner, and the Carriage overtook me just at Kensington Gate. I rode the rest of the way home, and after dinner went to Dr Nicholas’s School, and heard the conclusion of Mr Garrett’s Lecture. Mrs Adams did not go— It was upon the structure of the eye—Light—Vision—Catoptrics and Dioptrics—finishing with a Phantasmagoria. It was much more amusing than the Lecture of last Evening, and the boys were better pleased, and not quite so disorderly. The Professor’s language was as ludicrous as ever— “Ladies and Gentlemen—vy is my Coat black; and a sheet of paper vite?—it all shews the visdom of our adorable creator &c”— His phantasmagoria was good; but not equal to that we saw last Spring at Robertson’s at Paris. He exhibited shades of the Emperor Alexander, the king of Prussia, King George the 3d: Blucher and Nelson— The boys shouted and clapped their hands at the sight of all these figures. There was also a female figure, said to be of the late Princess Amelia— At this and some other female shades the boys clapped, and smacked their lips: which Dr Nicholas disapproved; and said to me smiling— “Hear now those rascals!” The Lecture finished again between nine and ten; and I walked home with George— The Miss Nicholas’s had spent the morning with Mrs: Adams, and Mr T. Dickason had paid us a visit, while I was in town— We received this Evening, a Card, of Mrs Morison, at home. Monday 18. December—directed to Mr & Mrs Adams, and family.

13. VI:15. Last Evening, I received a Letter, from the Brothers Baring, in reply to that which I wrote them on the 8th. instant— They promise compliance with my requests, and assure me that they have written to Mr M’Call accordingly. Also a Letter from my Son George written in French, to announce the Vacation at the school. This morning we had a Card from Mr and Mrs Von Harten, inviting us to dine with them on the 21st. Mr Grubb sent out Letters from Mr Maury at Liverpool, and from the Count de la Châtre, the French Ambassador. The latter contains a request to me to apply to the authorities at New-York, to give aid to the French Consul in the purpose of stopping payment of certain bills, drawn, as he states, by the house of Cazanova in London, upon that of Le Roy, Bayard and M’Evers at New-York. These Bills it alledges are drawn for account of a man named Auguste Marchal, a fraudulent cashier who absconded and escaped from France, with the money entrusted to him— The Count states that he demanded of the British Government that this man should be arrested, and was answered that he had probably followed his Bills to America— There is a document in English, enclosed with the Letter, as confirmative of the facts alledged in it; but instead of Bills of Exchange, it is a description of several Certificates of United States six per Cent Stock, transferred to Francis Marchal of Philadelphia, with the necessary Letters of Attorney to make the transfer— I do not exactly understand the case; for the Ambassador’s Letter refers to one set of papers, and the document enclosed shews another— The Bills he says amount to £10,000 Sterling, and the Certificates of Stock, are to the amount of 50,000 dollars.— Some further explanation seems to be necessary.— Mrs. Adams finished for me the Letter begun last Thursday, to Mr Russell, and wrote Letters to the Secretary of State and to Mr Maury— I walked to Gunnersbury and Brentford, and in the Evening, we went to the School at Ealing, and saw the slight of hand tricks with cards, and cups and Balls performed by Mr Jonas— He speaks English not quite so well as professor Garrett, but his tricks were performed with proper exterity as he called it, and his foreign accent saved him from the critical wantonness of the boys. We came home about ten.

14. VI: I enclosed by this Morning’s Post, the Letters yesterday prepared, to Mr J. A. Smith, at the Office in Charles Street— I put the Letter from Mr Hippisley to Captain Trenchard, under the cover to the Secretary of State, and the one for Mr Lawrence at Stockholm, under that to Mr Russell— By the morning Post, I received a card left at the Office by Mr John Oliver of Baltimore with Letters from Mr Hughes, the Secretary that was of the Ghent Legation, Mr George Boyd, and Mr Richard Forrest of Washington; also a Note from Mr J. C. Gray, sent to the Office, without direction, and enclosing the a five pound Note for that I had lent to Mr Very.— The Evening Post again brought Letters from Mr Maury at Liverpool, enclosing a despatch of 12. October last, from Mr J. A. Dallas, Secretary of the Treasury—from Mr G. W. Erving. 21. October at Philadelphia: and from Mr Beasley, enclosing Lists of the destitute American Seamen, sent by him to the United States, who had been discharged from the British Naval Service; into which most of them had been previously impressed— Also of Seamen to whom he has delivered certificates as Americans, to enable them to sell the Pensions to which they were entitled for service in the British Navy. The Letters from G. Boyd, R. Forrest, and one from C. Hughes, were only introductions, and very strong Recommendations of Mr Oliver. A second, and a long Letter from Hughes contained much information, and is written with all the pleasantry and good humour that belongs to his character— The Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury, encloses a copy of one of the same date to Messrs. Baring Brothers and Co. the same which Mr Alexander Baring shewed me on the 21st. of last Month— The Government have wisely determined not to attempt any further to dispose of the three Millions of six per Cent Stocks which were sent by Mr Boyd to us at Ghent, and Mr Dallas writes very confidently, that there will be hereafter no more protracted and tardy remittances. Mr Erving’s Letter is very short, and encloses one for the Duke of Sorentino— Mrs Adams wrote for me Letters to Mr Beasley and to my brother; and also made a copy of the latter.— I answered Mr Cobbett’s questions concerning the copy-rights in America. and send back the Letter. Mr Grubb has informed me that he had sent to Mr Beasley the copy of the Supplementary Act of Congress, which Mr Cobbett had not seen.— Dr: Nicholas’s two eldest daughters called upon Mrs: Adams. I walked to Hanwell and Ealing. Our sons John and Charles came home to dinner, and returned to School in the Evening with George, who was invited to a parting supper, given with Dr Nicholas’s permission, by his schoolmate Flexney, who is about to leave the school. George came home about eleven O’Clock.

15. VI:30. By the morning’s Post, I enclosed to Mr J. A. Smith the Letter yesterday prepared for Mr Beasley, to be copied, and returned with Mr Cobbetts Letter to him— And a packet for my father sealed, and containing with the last Sunday Observer, the Letter yesterday written to my brother— There were several Letters that came, addressed to Mrs Adams—which had
already been opened by another Mrs Adams, living in Ealing— They were answers to the enquiries, which my wife had written to make of the women Servants that she intended to engage instead of those she has dismissed— I received also Letters from Mr Grubb with enclosures— A Note from Mr Cooke, the Under-Secretary in the Department of Foreign Affairs, with information that Mr Aspinwall’s exequatur as American Consul for the Port of London, is ready to be delivered upon application to the Chief Clerk, and payment of the fees, amounting to £9:19— A Duplicate of the Letter yesterday received from Mr Dallas the Secretary of the Treasury, with its enclosure— A Letter from Mr Thomas English at Dublin, in reply to mine addressed to him on the 6th: instt:—he has, as I supposed, not received any new Commission as American Consul since the Peace; but Acts under the Commission which he had held before the War— Mrs Adams wrote for me a Letter to the Secretary of the Treasury, in reply to that which I yesterday received from him— And also a draft of an answer to Lord Castlereagh’s Note, concerning the destitute American Seamen.— In my walk before dinner I called and returned the visit of Mr Carr the Vicar of the Parish— He had left a card at my house one day when I was in town, a short time before my illness; and the other Evening the Miss Nicholas’s asked if I had returned the visit.— I had not, having at first been prevented by my confinement, and since my recovery by procrastination. I found him at home, and with a Lady not in very early youth, his daughter. He is near fourscore years of age, and though in good health somewhat infirm. He had a few American acquaintances among who he mentioned to me Bishop White of Philadelphia, and the late Mr Hamilton of Bush-Hill, and his family. The Old Gentleman seemed sometimes a little embarrassed between the desire of observing civility to me, and the current in which his ideas have been running perhaps all his life, but certainly more than forty years, in relation to America— He referred in the course of Conversation to the American revolution, and was about to call it the rebellion of the Colonies, but softened his expressions with an evident effort, and called it the time when America was throwing off the yoke. His daughter, who had been at the fencing exhibition at the school, complimented me upon the performance of my sons; particularly the two youngest— Mrs Carr the Parson’s wife has been for some years nearly blind, and at the age of seventy seven, was about a month since couched for Cataracts, by the great oculist Sir William Adams. The operation was at first said to have been perfectly successful; but now Sir William says, there is a film still to be removed from one of the eyes; and the old Lady’s nerves have been so shaken by the first operation that they have not yet ventured to tell her of the necessity of a second— This Mr Carr’s son, Coll: Sir Henry Carr, is the person whom the widow of the late prime Minister Mr Perceval, married to the great surprize of the public. They reside at Ealing, but have a house also in town— Mr Carr told me, that he was to have dined with us at the proposed Club, this day, but had afterwards recollected an engagement at home— I shortened my walk, the roads being very bad, and after returning home, went out again, just before six to the dinner— It was at theInn; kept by a Mr Laws, and seems particularly patronized by Dr Nicholas— There were six persons present— The Doctor, Mr Von Harten, Major Morison, Mr Copland, a Mr Gifford, whom I had never seen before, and myself— Mr Gray was engaged in London, so that he was unable to attend. There were some other Gentlemen of the neighbourhood, who had been expected, but had not been persuaded to come— There was some old grudge between them and Mr Laws, which Dr Nicholas is endeavouring to smooth down with some prospect, of success. The dinner had been ordered for eight at seven shillings a head, and the wine to be paid apart— We had a very good dinner, and fair wines, particularly the Port. We parted between ten and eleven O’Clock, and the Bill amounted to 17/6 a head— We agreed to meet and dine at the same house again, on Friday, the 13th: of January, and ordered a dinner again for eight— Dr Nicholas is going in the mean time to Wales, to visit his father, 86 years of age, and now very ill, but he expect to return before that day. The party was social and agreeable; and I can join in conversation with these gentlemen, on any topics other than politics, upon which when introduced I am of course silent— Mr Copland came from London to attend the dinner, and returned to town this Night. When I came home, I found the two eldest Miss Nicholas’s spending the Evening with Mrs Adams— They soon afterwards left us.

16. VII:15. The last day of George’s attendance at School for the present term— The vacation commences on the 21st. but more than half of the boys are already gone, and the exercises of the school are all at an end— This week has been devoted almost entirely to speaking. All the boys speak— But they have their pieces assigned to them, and forty or fifty of them speak the same— George’s Class spoke Collins’s Ode on the Passions— John and Charles, Hotspur reading the Letter— They all acquitted themselves creditably— The Morning hour for opening the school has been put back a quarter of an hour every fortnight, in November and December, from seven to eight O’Clock. I enclosed this morning to Mr J. A. Smith, the Letter yesterday prepared for the Secretary of the Treasury, and the paper sent me by the French Ambassador, with his Letter— Mrs Adams wrote for me a Letter to my father, in answer to that received by Mr Smith—and also, one to Mr Pitcairn at Hamburg, requesting him to procure for me, and send me Bode’s Uranographia— This has been suggested to me, by the view of the skies and of the Stars from my chamber windows, every clear morning, and if I had Bode’s
Charts, I could turn them to use, for the instruction of my Sons. Received Letters from Mr Louis Casamajor, from Mr Maury, and from my father, dated 3. November— Mr Casamajor is going as Secretary to the British Embassy at St: Peterburg. Mrs: Adams when she left Russia, was commissioned to purchase some Articles of finery for Lady Porter, and had made the purchases at Paris; but had not found an opportunity of sending them to her. As Mr Casamajor was an old acquaintance of ours, having been in America, with Mr Rose, Mrs Adams thought he would take these Articles, and I some time since at her request asked Mr Morier, if he thought Mr Casamajor would do this good Office— He promised to enquire; and now Mr Casamajor with great civility offers to take any thing, if it be not of a size to bulky for a pretty well loaded Carriage— Mr Maury complains bitterly of the burden of destitute American Seamen, with which he is overloaded, and informs me that he has taken up a vessel to send about one hundred of them home, and intends giving the Ship-Owners his Bills upon the Government for their passages. He also mentions that an American Vessel from Baltimore, has been taken by a revenue Cutter, in an attempt to smuggle tobacco, on the Coast of Ireland— The crew, more than thirty, are at Liverpool, applying to him for relief, to which he thinks them not entitled— He asks my opinion— My walk this day was to Hanwell and Ealing— In the Evening Mrs Adams read to me, in Tucker’s Light of Nature.

17. VI:15. I have hitherto not ventured to write by candle-light; so that my progress in retrieving the arrears of this Journal has been slower than I had expected and intended. I have indeed for these three weeks generally risen an hour or more before day-light, but it has been employed in hearing George read; and as soon as the dusk of Evening came on I was again obliged to lay aside my pen— As my eyes however gradually recover strength, and I recover the freer use of my hand I find myself able to write more; and this morning I began to Journalize by Candle-light, and on returning from my walk before dinner, wrote again from five until six O’Clock— As the record of each day becomes more prolix as I gain upon the arrears, unless I could write more than I have yet effected, I should soon cease to gain upon the arrears at all.— I went to Church this morning with George. The prayers were read, and the Sermon delivered by Dr Bond; a Clergyman who resides and keeps a small School at Hanwell. It was the best written Discourse that I ever heard from the Pulpit in England. His text was taken from the Lesson of the day; which is the third Sunday in Advent—the subject was the duties of a Christian Preacher, and those of his hearers in relation to him— It was eloquent and pathetic. His delivery was good, but had rather more of the theatrical manner of speaking than is agreeable to me— Mr J. A. Smith came out from London, and George’s School-mates John Newman, the Captain of the School, and Watson, dined with us— They returned immediately after dinner, and Mrs Adams, with Mr Smith and George went and passed the Evening at Dr Nicholas’s— I had retired to bed long before they returned home.

18. VI: When I went up to George’s chamber to call him up this Morning, I found he had not passed the Night there. He slept in the chamber below, with Mr Smith, and I did not see him until breakfast time. He read after breakfast— The annual Latin Play was to be performed for the third time, this Evening by the Scholars of Westminster school, and Dr Nicholas had procured three tickets for us. I went into London with Mr Smith and George— I stopped at the corner of Downing Street, went to the foreign Office, and took out Coll: Aspinwall’s Commission, with the Exequatur— Mr Bidwell, the chief Clerk was not there, but there was an under Clerk, who received the fees—£9:19. and delivered to me the papers. I then went to my Office in Charles Street, and sent the Servant Richard, to Mr Louis Casamajor, with the parcel made up by Mrs Adams, for Lady Porter, and a Note to him, requesting him if the packet should be too large, to send it back— At the Office I found Letters from William Parry, Thomas Cook of George town , J. S. Cogdell of South Carolina, and Mr Maury— Parry is a manufacturer of fire-arms or Ordinance, who has been to me several times and who wants to go to America. He is, or fancies himself a great inventor or improver, and has written several volumes about gunnery, and the composition of Gunpowder, which he wishes the American Government to buy— He is moreover like all the other disappointed projectors, who have come to me in this Country a malcontent and a republican. I have been much upon the reserve with them all— This man how ever found out Commodore Barney when he was here, who as he says promised to recommend him to the Government. He now sends me a Letter for the Commodore, with a box containing the four important volumes of manuscript, to be forwarded to him, and by him to the City of Washington— The Letter to me is merely to request me to transmit them, which I some time ago promised Parry that I would.— Mr Cook’s letter, enclosed one for my wife, and one for Mr Murdoch, which I sent him by the two-Penny Post. The purport of them all was to inform us of the Death of our friend and brother in Law, Mr Walter Hellen, of the City of Washington— He had been many years in a very infirm state of health, most of them time confined to his house, and scarcely expected to live from week to week.
He had successively married Nancy and Adelaide Johnson, the eldest and the youngest sister of my wife; the latter of whom survives him; with one daughter of her own, and three children of the first wife. Mr Cook, the Executor of his will, sends me an Extract from it— His son Johnson, is substituted as the Executor, if Mr Cook should die after he comes of age; and in case of his Death, the trust is to devolve upon me. The widow and Children are left in comfortable circumstances— He died on the 30th. of October, and we had already received information of the Event, by letters from Mrs Smith at New-York to my wife, which were brought by Mr J. A. Smith— Mr Cogdell is one of the persons who wrote to me, expressing the wish to receive the appointment of Secretary of Legation to this Court, and whose Letter, I answered in August last— This Letter is in reply— He professes to be satisfied with what I wrote him on the subject; and informs me of his intention to visit England, the ensuing Spring.— Mr Maury mentions that instead of one hundred destitute Seamen, he shall be able to send home not more than fifty by the vessel mentioned in his last preceding Letter. I had written to enquire of him the cause of the extraordinary numbers of these applications to him for relief— He answers the question, in this Letter, but not entirely to my satisfaction— After perusing these Letters, I left the Office with George to go to N. 68 Lombard Street, to receive of Martin, Stone and Martin, Bankers, payment of the Bill of Exchange drawn by Meyer & Brüxner of St: Petersburg, upon John Mitchell, which was payable this day, and assigned at the Bank of Martin and Co: I had not reached the Corner of Charles Street, when I met Mr Glennie the son, with Mr Karthaus, and turned back with them— I told Mr Karthaus, that I should make the application to this Government, for restitution to the owner of the Baltimore, and her Cargo; but that to have any prospect of success additional evidence of the facts, would be indispensably necessary; most especially of the fact of the capture within the Spanish Jurisdiction— The only evidence of that, included in the papers, was the Captain’s Protest, signed also by the Mate; but that is scarcely ever received as evidence at-all.— It stated that there was a Spanish Pilot on board, at the time of the capture; the testimony of that Pilot, and of his boat’s crew, would be worth more as evidence than a hundred Protests, and if some such testimony should not be produced, the Government here as soon as they received my Note, would refer it to the Captain of the Ship who made the capture, and take his report whatever it might be, as a decisive answer to the complaint. Mr Karthaus, who appeared to have no idea, of any difficulty from the want of Evidence, asked me to let him have the papers for a few days, to ascertain what facts it might be necessary to authenticate by substantial proof, and accordingly took them with him— He and Mr Glennie, took leave, and I made a second attempt to go down into the City— I was again met before we reached the corner of Charles Street by Coll: Aspinwall, who was going to my Office, and with whom I again turned back. I gave him his Commission and the exequatur, and had some conversation with him concerning the destitute Seamen, who are now turned over to him by Mr Beasley— I wished to shew him the Note that I propose to send in answer to that of Lord Castlereagh, and invited him to come with his family and dine with us next Monday. He said he would consult Mrs Aspinwall and send me an Answer— After he went away, I made the third attempt, with George to go down into the City, and this time, we succeeded— It was half past three when we left the City, and precisely five when we returned to it— The distance is about 2 1/2 miles, but the crowds of people thronging the Streets, which were greater than usual made it impossible to walk fast— I received payment of the Bill, and immediately returned, with out having time to stop a moment to purchase a pair of skaits for John as I had promised him— We had taken into town a cold dinner, which we found ready at the Office; we had scarcely dispatched it, when Dr Nicholas called for us. He had appointed half past five O’Clock, and rather preceded his time. I found on the table a Letter from Count Fernan Nuñez, the Spanish Ambassador, which I had not then time to read, and put in my pocket— Dr Nicholas immediately took us to Mr Knox, one of the Masters of the school; whose first salutation upon seeing us was, that we could not all have places— There were only four of us, including the Doctor, and we all had tickets— After some coaxing however, Mr Knox finally consented to take us all in, and when we were introduced, I was a little surprized to find there was nobody there— It was about half an hour before the company began to come, and past seven, when the Play began— The Duke of York was expected, but he went this morning to Brighton. I saw there Count Beroldingen the Minister of Wurtemberg, Count Jenison-Walworth, Secretary of the Bavarian Legation, and Mr Hamilton the Under Secretary of State— The place fitted up for a theatre was the dormitory of the king’s scholars. And the names of great numbers of the former pupils are painted in capitals round the walls. It seems to be intended as a distinction, but is done without taste or order, and in most instances like the Critics in the temple of Fame, the new names are painted over the old ones and efface them— The room was finally crowded with Company. The Play performed was Terence’s Andria— The Prologue was very badly spoken, and was a panegyric upon the Discipline of the British schools; with a dire proportion of abuse upon France and Germany— All which was very highly applauded. The Orator had an impediment in his speech
and could scarcely articulate. His gesture was as ungracious as his pronunciation, and he made his bows like a Magot de la Chine, all from the Neck. Dr Nicholas told me that by an established Custom the Prologue must always be spoken by the Captain of the School— It was therefore almost always badly spoken; and was never expected to be otherwise. The Speaker of the Prologue had no part in the Play; which was well performed— Not better however than the Adelphi had been at Ealing. The Epilogue was a dialogue between two of the Personages of the Play, in which Davus and Crito, make sport with some of the ridiculous things of the present or recent times— The invisible Lady, the Indian Jugglers swallowing swords, Joanna Southcott the pregnant old woman, and most of all Dr Gall and Spurzheim’s Craniology.— It was not altogether without wit and humour. The Prologue and Epilogue were both spoken twice; a strange practice, for the convenience of the semi-latinists who can understand better with two hearings than with one— He told me that he had attempted when he began exhibiting these Plays to have these head and tail pieces spoken only once; but the repetition was called for by the spectators, and he had been obliged to conform to the Westminster usage— The Dr introduced me to Mr Fletcher of Ealing, who was there, with his Son, the late Captain of Ealing School and principal performer, at the Play there in September last— The exhibition was over about ten O’Clock, and I took Dr Nicholas home to his house— He had gone to town in a Post-Chaise— Richard, my footman, gave me a packet which had been left for me at the Office, since I was there this Evening— We set Mr J. A. Smith down at Charing Cross, and after landing Dr Nicholas at his house, came home, where we arrived before Midnight— George was quite unwell— He had a remnant of his old cough hanging about him; and this day wet his feet through in walking with me to the City— After reaching home I opened the Letter from the Spanish Ambassador, and that given me by Richard as we left Westminster School. Count Fernan Nuñez informs me that he has received orders from his Court to demand restitution of the William and Mary; that he has accordingly addressed a Note to the British Ministry to make the demand, and will communicate to me their answer, when he shall have received it— The other Packet was from a Mr Anthony M’Kenrot, enclosing a Letter addressed “A Son Altesse Impériale, Le Prince Joseph Bonaparte, à New-York, en Amerique,” with a request from M’Kenrot to me, that I would forward it to its destination— This man wrote me once before, an impertinent Letter, and is now under a process of examination for the forgery of Bills of Exchange to a large amount— He says the Austrian Ambassador has forwarded such Letters for him— In our walk into the City his day, I was struck with the Gazlights which are introduced in the Streets, and most of the shops in the neighbourhood of the Mansion House— They are remarkably brilliant, and shed a light almost too dazzling for my eyes— They are also attended with an inconvenience of offensive smell, which I thought perceptible even in the Streets—and they are thought to be unhealthy. For lighting Streets however and open places, it is probable they will supersede the use of Oil— Our Sons John and Charles, this Evening came home from School, for the vacation of the Christmas Holidays— Mrs Adams sent an apology to Mrs Morison for our not attending her Rout this Evening.

19. VII:15. There was a fall of Snow this morning, which covered the ground, but it disappeared again before Night— Mr Huxley, one of the Masters at Ealing School came, and agreed to give lessons of writing and Arithmetic to our Sons, during the Vacation— I had at first thought of engaging him for three hours every week day, and keeping a school-room for the boys to give them employment. But as he asked half a guinea a day for this, and teaches only writing and cyphering, I engaged him for one hour at a time; four days in the week—to begin next Saturday—at five shillings a lesson— Mr John Chipman Gray, came from Town and paid us a short visit, but went away, while I was engaged with Mr Huxley— I went with Mrs Adams and paid a visit to Mr & Mrs Dickason at Twickenham Common. We saw Mrs Dickason, but her husband had gone this morning into London— They purpose to remove into town for the Season, next week. I had taken with me the letter I received yesterday from the Spanish Ambassador, to shew it to Mr Dickason— As we returned, I left the Carriage at the turning of the Brentford and Windsor road, and walked round by Gunnersbury, home. We had left at our house the two eldest Miss Nicholas’s, Caroline and Ellen, and found them again on our return; they dined and spent the Evening with us.

20. VI:15. A Storm of Rain, which continued almost the whole day— I wrote to Messrs. Dickason and Nevett, to give them the information received from the Spanish Ambassador— Mrs Adams went into Town and took John and Charles with her— She paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Hewlett, and called to see Mrs Aspinwall, but missed of finding her.— Mr Grubb had mistaken the number of the Colls lodgings. She returned home about five O’Clock— I met the Carriage returning, in my walk through Brentford, during the intervals of the holding up of the rain— In the Evening it cleared away Cold. I was occupied all day, in writing my
Journal— I sent back to Mr M’Kenrot, the Letter addressed to his Imperial Highness Prince Joseph Bonaparte, which I declined to transmit— Mrs Adams brought out from London a Letter received at the Office, signed C. Cleland, of Boston, and dated at the New Prison, White Cross Street London— He is a young man not yet twenty-two, son of Mr: William Cleland of Boston, whom I well remember to have seen at a visitation of the Schools at Boston in the year 1807, and who was then remarked as exhibiting the most beautiful specimens of hand-writing that were shewn at any one of the schools— He now writes from a jail, into which he has been plunged as he confesses, by his own follies, and from which he implores my assistance to recover him. He speaks of his own misconduct in general terms, and avowedly avoids particular details, because “his heart is too full to attempt the task.” I fear his case is a bad one— After dinner this Evening I set my sons John and Charles to reading passages in Shakespear— George’s cough has become severe again.

21. VI:15. The trunks of the children were brought from the school this Morning, and the Bills for their schooling were sent with them— They amount, within two shillings to one hundred pounds Sterling— In my walk before dinner I went round by the school, called upon the Doctor, and paid the Bill— He is going in the course of two or three days for Wales, being detained to-morrow to attend a Meeting of a Charitable Association for the relief of Schoolmasters, decayed, and their widows, of which the Duke of Kent is the Patron. The Duke, he said has sent him a message with a particular request that he would attend to-morrow— He was very full of conversation, and told me that the Duke of Norfolk, just deceased had left, he heard eighty-seven natural children— He also told me a long, and curious Story of his particular friend General Knowles, who is indisputably entitled to the Earldom of Banbury, and was personally advised by the king to prosecute his right before the house of Peers; but was defeated there, by the intrigues of the Duke of Cumberland, and of the Chancellor, merely because Knowles was a Foxite, and not cautious enough in suppressing his opinions. This day we discharged three women Servants. Mrs. Mary Brooks the Cook—Margaret Wedge the House-maid and Ann Prudden, the Laundry maid— These household concerns employed so much of the morning, that we had not much time left for writing. I finally prepared however the Note to Lord Castlereagh, relative to destitute American Seamen, and Mrs Adams made out a fair copy of it to be taken to town— We dined at Mr Von Harten’s, where we met Dr Nicholas, his sons Frank and George, and his daughters Caroline and Ellen— Major and Mrs Morison, Miss Carnell and Miss Blair, Mr and Mrs Moss, Mr Clifton and his Son, Mr Becker, Mr Rahles and Mr Eschenbach— The three last of these Gentlemen are Germans— Mr Becker mentioned having dined in company with me last February at Mr Hottinguer’s in Paris. Mr and Mrs Moss, and Mr Clifton reside in the neighbourhood, to which Mr Clifton has very lately removed from Richmond— The dinner was very agreeable, and would have been more so, but for a cold dining room. We sat late at table, and had no music by the Ladies after dinner— It was eleven O’Clock when we came home. I found a Letter from Mr Karthaus, sending me back the papers, of his case, and requesting me to write to the American Consuls at Madrid or Cadix, and direct them to obtain for him the evidence required for him at St Andero. And a Letter from Mr Gulian Ludlow of New-York, dated 18 November, acknowledging the receipt of the Papers which I sent him by Mr Pedersen, and promising to execute my instructions concerning them. We also found that our New Cook, Mary Payne, and House-maid, Mary Beach had arrived. This morning I received a Note from Coll: Aspinwall, with an excuse for not dining with us next Monday, owing to a previous engagement for Christmas day, of which Mrs Aspinwall had reminded him.

22. VII:30. I completed, my Journal for the month of November, and thus brought up all the arrears from the time when I met the accident which disabled me from writing, until the day when I effectually resumed the pen to retrieve the record of the time elapsed. But it has taken me much longer than I expected, and made a new chasm of arrears amounting to three weeks. George was this day so unwell with his cough that I did not hear him read. I went into Town, and took with me the Note to Lord Castlereagh, while Mr Smith was making the copy of it to be sent in I took the Letter for the Duke of Sorentino, Marquis of Salinas, which had been enclosed to me by Mr Erving, and carried it to the house where the Duke had lodged last Summer. He was no longer there, but the woman of the house described to me the house in which he now resides, so that I easily found it—N. 84. Piccadilly— Neither the Duke, nor the Duchess, who is now with him was at home. I left Mr Erving’s Letter, and a Card, and returned to Charles Street, through the Park. Mr Smith had the Note for Lord Castlereagh ready, but it became necessary to have another copy made— I left him therefore my signature, with directions to send the Note in to-morrow Morning— I had ordered the Carriage at four, and at half past
three left the Office, and walked until the Carriage overtook me. It was just beyond the five Mile Stone from Hyde Park corner, and it was so dark, that they nearly passed by without perceiving me. They however heard me call, and I rode the rest of the way home— Richard brought me a Letter from Mr Judah Hays, at Naples, to Mr Grubb, received by him after I had left the Office— It mentions how Mr Hays had forwarded the Letters for Mr Shaler and Commodore Decatur, which we had entrusted to him. We also received Answers to the Cards of Invitation which Mrs Adams had sent to several Gentlemen the day before yesterday; to dine with us next Monday.
