Mr Astor (who came a fellow passenger with Mr J. A. Smith) declines, and went off this morning for Paris. Mr Snow is gone— The others accept. I received also a Letter from Messrs: Thomas Dickason and Co. in answer to mine of the 20th. Mr Dickason will see me upon the business— George read this Evening, but his cough and Charles’s are both very bad.

23. VI:30. Mrs Adams wrote for me a short Note to Lord Castlereagh, concerning the discrimination made between British and American Vessels, with regard to the exportation of passengers from Ireland; a subject upon which I have received two Letters from Mr English, acting as American Consul at Dublin, and upon which I spoke some time since to the Under-Secretary of State Hamilton. She also wrote Letters to the President of the United States, the Secretary of State, and Mr Karthaus— That to the President was to enclose the pamphlet which the Chevalier de Llaño, some time since sent to me for him.— The despatch to the Secretary of State, was to transmit, with copies of the late Correspondence concerning destitute American Seamen— Mr Karthaus is advised to obtain from St: Andero, the Evidence necessary for his cause, himself— Mr Huxley came and gave his first Lesson of writing and Arithmetick during the vacation, to our three Sons— I had a visit from Mr Frederick Pursh, to whom I lent ten pounds Sterling more to enable him to return to the United States; taking his promissory Note for its repayment; in duplicates as before. He had sent last week to the Office a Copy of his Flora Americae Septentrionalis; but I had only received and brought it out from town, last Evening.— It is in two Octavo Volumes with 24 Plates. I have not had time yet to read over his preface— He told me that it had cost him £600 Sterling to collect the materials and compose this work, and that he had obtained only £80. for the Copy-Right. But it was only upon these terms that he could obtain the publication of the book. He proposes to continue the same pursuits on his return to America, and hopes to form an establishment there for the improvement of Botany, Gardening and Agriculture in general— Upon a plan something similar to the école d’agriculture at Paris. He asked me for Letters of recommendation to gentlemen in America, who might assist him in these views of public utility, and I promised to give him some—to be ready for him next Saturday, when he is to call for them at my Office— He expects immediately afterwards to embark in the Nabby, for New-York— I walked to Hanwell and Ealing— Mrs Adams sent Pio to town, who on his return brought out Letters from Mr Grubb, Mr Maury, and Mr A. H. Everett— Mr Maury has been disappointed of his engagement to send home a vessel’s load of destitute American Seamen, the agent for the vessel now declining to ship more than the number required by law. Mr Everett’s Letter, is in answer to mine of the 6th: instt. and was brought by Mr G. H. Apthorp— He also mentions having sent me a book by General Turreau upon the Institutions and Politics of the United States—But the Book was not with the Letter— Turreau said something to me about this Book, when I saw him last Spring at Paris, but I did not see it. I understood him it was not favourable to us; but Everett says it is a telum imbelle sine ictu— George reads, but not without difficulty.

24. VI: Mr J. A. Smith was to have come out from London this day; but being unwell, sent us word last Evening that he should probably not come out until to-morrow. George and Charles were both so much effected by their coughs that neither they nor Mrs: Adams went to Church— I went with John— Prayers for the fourth Sunday in Advent were read by Mr Lewis, and the Sermon from 2. Timothy. II. 19. “Let every one that nameth the name of Christ, depart from iniquity,” by Mr Carr, the Vicar. The Old Gentleman reads remarkably well; but his Sermons are very dull and heavy. I was engaged all the leisure of the day in writing my Journal.— Anniversary of the signature of the Peace of Ghent.

25. Christmas Day— I went to Church with John, who was reluctant to go upon a week day, and pleaded that Christmas keeping was not a part of his religion— I wished however to see the religious celebration of the day according to all the forms of the English Church, and in England— I had never seen it myself, though I had already passed two Christmas days in the Country—the first in 1783. and the second in 1795. The Church was internally decorated with ever-greens, as are the episcopalian churches in America— Mr Carr, read the whole Christmas day’s service, including the Creed of St: Athanasius. The Sermon was preached by Mr Lewis—from 1. John 11.12 [“]He came unto his own, and his own received him not— But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name.”— It was one of the most indifferent Sermons
that I ever heard from this Gentleman, who is here Mr Carr’s assistant at £80 a Year; but who is said to be going to India, upon a salary of £800— The Church was about as well attended as it is usually on Sunday Morning’s, but nearly half its auditory consists of School-boys and girls, whose seats are now all deserted for the vacation, excepting about twenty of Dr: Nicholas’s pupils who remain all the holidays at his house.— The communion, or as they call it the most comfortable sacrifice of the body and blood of Christ, was administered, but there were not more than ten persons who stayed to receive it— Mr Carr gave notice that to-morrow being the festival of St Stephen, the next day, that of St John, and Thursday that of the Holy Innocents, were to be kept as Holidays, and the Church services would be performed— The Clerk, Mr Atlee gave notice that this Evening’s service would begin at three O’Clock, but I did not attend it. After church I walked round through Brentford, where the Christmas dainties, were passing to and fro, about the Streets, from the Cook’s, Baker’s and Confectioner’s shops. All the four Miss Nicholas’s paid Mrs Adams a visit. Mr J. A. Smith came out from town about three O’Clock— I was engaged writing upon my Journal until five, and then read the Preface of Mr Pursh’s Flora of North-America— Messrs: Allston, Bennett, J. C. Gray, Joy, Oliver and Reynolds, dined with us. They all came in a Carriage together excepting Mr Gray who arrived here at ten O’Clock in the Evening, and just before we had risen from table. Mr Reynolds had agreed to come out in company with him, but by some mistake at Mr Gray’s lodgings, was told there when he called for him this day, that he had been two or three days out of town, and was not expected to return— Reynolds therefore came out with the other Gentlemen, and Gray who had returned home at the appointed hour of four O’Clock, waited for him until eight or nine, and then came out alone— He said he had dined; but I believe that was to save us the trouble of having dinner brought back for him. He was much incensed with Mr Reynolds, and on first coming in could not suppress his feelings— After an exhaustion however he was pacified, and put up with a remnant of dinner, such as was to be got— It was near eleven when we left the Table, and the Gentlemen soon departed. I shewed Mr Allston, my Print of the Battle on Lake Erie; but he was not pleased with it— I received this day a second Letter of importunity from the man at the Custom-House-Lock— And a Letter from Mr Eustis at the Hague, which appears by the Superscription, to have been brought by Mr Delprat.

26. VII: Mr J. A. Smith had brought out a Note from Coll. Aspinwall to Mr Grubb, proposing to engage him as a Clerk in the Consulate, on the Assurances, as it stated, I had given, that the expence for Clerk-hire, would be allowed, by the Government of the United States— I was apprehensive that the Coll: had understood me as pledging the Government, which it was not my intention and which I have no authority to do— An explanation was necessary— Other objects also made it necessary for me to go to town; but it was so late before we set out, that it was almost three when we reached the Office in Charles Street.— For the Accommodation, and convenience of Mr Smith I have consented that the Office should be kept at his lodgings, and as the Apartments at Charles Street, are not suitable for both the purposes, he has been looking out for others— He had found a place which suited him at N. 13. Craven Street between the Strand and the river; and I went with him and looked at the Chambers— I found them such as might answer— The price asked for them was 2 1/2 guineas a week; and I agreed that he should take them, if they are to be had for two guineas— One guinea a week is to be allowed for the Office, the same which has been paid at Charles Street— Mr Smith has lodged since last Tuesday at the Office, but does not find the apartments there comfortable. I ordered the Coachman to put up his horses at the owners stable, and at four O’Clock to start with them for home, without returning to the Office— Mr Smith copied and signed the short Note for Lord Castlereagh, which was prepared last Saturday. I left the other papers with him. I gave Mr Grubb, young Cleland’s Letter, requesting him to call and see him at the prison, and enquire into the circumstances of his case; to ascertain whether I can give him any assistance— I was dictating to Mr Grubb, a Letter to Mr Aspinwall, when he himself came in— I then told him that wishing to avoid all misunderstanding of what I had said to him respecting an allowance to be made by the Government for the necessary expences of Clerk hire, I was writing to him to say that I had no authority to pledge the Government to any thing in the case— I had thought it so obviously reasonable that the expences should be paid, that I had inferred they would not refuse the payment. But it was merely the expression of my opinion; and I could not promise that the Government would concur in it. The Coll: said he had not understood me otherwise; but he came to ask me, first for an Order upon Messrs: Baring Brothers & Co: for money to pay for the support and the passages of destitute American Seamen—and Secondly an Order to him, to take charge of those Sailors as Agent for Seamen, an Office under which the Government would allow the expences, while they would not to the Consul— He had applied to the Baring’s for Money, but they had declined paying it without an order from me— I told him that I would give him the order on the Baring’s from the necessity of the case, though I had no authority from the Government so to do— I must take the responsibility upon myself, and I gave him an order for £300 Sterling. As to the order to him, to act as Agent for Seamen, I had no authority to give it, and I did not perceive
the absolute necessity for it. He had been told it was the President’s intention not to continue the Office of Agent for Seamen at London— He supposed that in time of Peace it would not be necessary. From the information which the Government would now receive, I trusted the necessity of continuing the Office, at least for some time longer, or of charging the Consul with its functions would be apparent— But as I now made myself responsible for the funds to defray the expences, I thought he must assume that of acting until the determination of the President can be known. Else it would be a mere transfer of the responsibility, from him to me— The Coll: seemed to be not entirely satisfied with this reasoning, and when Mr Grubb asked him if he should call upon him to-morrow, he said he believed not—for he knew that the charge of Clerk-hire would not be allowed him by the Government.— It was just upon four O’Clock, when he left the Office, and I immediately began my walk— The Carriage over took me about half way down hyde-Park— I stopped at a Druggists shop in Kensington and took boxes of Soda powders, and of Lozenges of Tolu— The roads were bad, and it was near six, when I reached home.

27. V:30. George is so ill with his cough, that he is unable to rise early in the morning to read. I have thus all the time before breakfast, at my own disposal, and as yet employ it to retrieve the Journal.— Mr Huxley gave the children a lesson— Mrs. Adams wrote Letters for me to my Mother, in answer to those from her, brought by Mr J. A. Smith, and to Mr Maury at Liverpool in reply to four Letters from him. My walk was to Brentford and Ealing; but the roads are so bad by the thaw that they are scarcely passable on foot— From the beginning of this month, there has been a continual succession of frost and thaw almost every second day. To save time to-morrow Morning, I made up the packet of Letters for Mr J. A. Smith to be then ready.

28. VI: Sent Mr Smith by the morning Post, the packet made up for him last Evening.— Received a Letter from Mr: Grubb enclosing one left at the Office with a Card, by Mr John Delafield. It is from Mr William Payne of Boston, dated 27. October last; merely an introduction of Mr Delafield, whom Mr Payne mentions as his nephew, settled and married in London— Mr Grubb has been to the new Prison, and seen young Cleland, from whom he received an account of the follies which have brought him into that situation. He has been much more than imprudent and extravagant, so that I scarcely know whether it will be possible for me to do any thing for him— He is now in prison for a debt of more than £100 Sterling to Hughes & Duncan of Liverpool, and being utterly unable to pay any part of it, he is equally without means of extricating himself from the prison. Mrs Adams wrote a Letter for me to Mr Hughes of Baltimore, and I made draughts of Letters to the French and Spanish Ambassadors, in answer to those which on the 13th. and 18 instts. I received from them— Mrs Adams made fair copies of them, which in the Evening I made up to be sent by the Post, to-morrow Morning— Walk to Gunnersbury and Brentford; but as yesterday, shorter than usual, owing to the foulness of the roads— Part of the Evening we played at Loto with the Children, two of whom are still confined with obstinate coughs to the house.

29. V:45. Dispatched the Letters to the two Ambassadors this Morning, and with them, that for Mr Hughes to Mr J. A. Smith to be copied— Mrs Adams wrote for me, Letters to the President of the United States, to Mr R. King and to Mr O. Wolcott, to be taken by Mr Pursh, and recommending him to their countenance and assistance in his scientific pursuits— Also an Answer to the Letter from Mr T. Cook of Georgetown, respecting the decease, and last Will of Mr Hellen— Mr Grubb sent me back, young Cleland’s Letter, and one in three and a half sheets of Paper from Mr Bourne at Amsterdam; a reply to that which I wrote him concerning the education of his Son, and further solicitations for Consular compensation— I had another muddy walk, to Ealing and Brentford— This Evening Mrs Adams had a Letter from Mr Grubb enclosing his account for sundry commissions executed by him— He mentions in it that he has been engaged for the consulate; so that the Coll: must have reconsidered his resolution of last Tuesday. We played Boston this Evening with the Children.

30. VI. George has with the exception of one day last week, continued his reading until this day; his cough is now so bad, that we must suspend it for some days.— John had received from his schoolmate Baker a Letter proposing to meet him in town, and I took him in with me. I found Mr G. H. Apthorp at the Office— He has been in Holland from the time when I saw him last Summer until his return, within these few days.— He says he has been doing business to a very large amount— That it is not yet finished, and he expects to go back there in about two Months— I asked him if Mr Everett had given him General Turreau’s book for me—he had not— He says that Mr Eustis has a good house at the Hague, but Mrs Eustis complains much of the want of Society— Neither of
them speaks French. Mr Apthorp says there has been very little commerce direct from the United States to Holland, this year, and that he has been astonished at the general decay in the circumstances of the People, in that Country. My own remark, when I was there last year was quite different; but I merely passed through the Country, and could see nothing by the surface— That, was in many respects improved. The appearance of comfort, cleanliness and plenty was the same— But different persons see with different eyes— I made some further enquiries of Mr Grubb concerning young Cleland, of whose conduct since he has been in the prison, he says the people there, speak very favourably.— Grubb suggested the idea of writing on the subject to Mr Maury, and said that perhaps Hughes and Duncan who have been for many years largely concerned in American business, and are wealthy men, might agree to release him from prison, upon an engagement by him ratified by his father to pay the money due, by instalments— I settled Accounts with Mr Grubb, with whom I am now very reluctantly to part— I have found him trusty, industrious, and obliging.— He asked me to write him some time when I should have leisure, a certificate, that I was satisfied with his services; which I very readily promised.— I also give up from this time the Apartments which I have kept, for an Office, at N. 25. Charles Street, Westminster— Mr J. A. Smith has taken the chambers at N. 13. Craven Street, at two Guineas a week, one of which is to be allowed for Office-Rent; and he has already removed thither his own effects— Those of the Office are to be removed on Monday— Mr Grubb keeps my private Letter-Book, to finish copying some Letters, of which I had only Press-copies, and which I wished to have entered in the Book— John’s Schoolmates the two Baker’s called at two, to meet him, and they went together to Westminster Abbey— I left with Mr Smith to be copied and delivered to Mr Pursh, the Letters written yesterday to send by him. I had ordered the Carriage at half past three. When John returned from the walk with his friends, I left him at the Office to follow me in the Carriage and walked on. They over took me at Kew Bridge, but I chose to finish my walk, and reached home in two hours and forty minutes from Charles Street. Ten minutes longer than the time before; but the walking is not so good as it was then— George was so ill that Mrs Adams sent while I was in town for Dr Cook, who came and prescribed both for him, and for Charles— George he says, has a slight inflammation of the lungs; he gives him Calomel, and talks of bleeding him to-morrow. Charles has only a Cold. I received a Letter this Evening from Mr G. Joy, enclosing for my perusal, a late one from Mr Eustis to him, with his answer. Consular compensations still— Mr Joy sent also a very pleasant Letter to my Son John with an English Copy of Valpy’s Greek Grammar for one of the American Edition, which he borrowed last Monday—and some Lozenges of Tolu for George and Charles.

31. VI:15. Attended Church this morning with John; all the rest of the family being prevented by indisposition— The service for the first Sunday after Christmas was read by Mr Carr, who announced that to-morrow would be a religious festival, being the day of the celebration of the Circumcision of Christ, and next Saturday, being that of the manifestation of Christ to the Gentiles. He also declared that he should administer the Communion next Sunday— The Sermon was preached by Mr Lewis—from XI. Hebrews. 7. “By faith Noah, being warned of God of things not seen as yet, moved with fear, prepared an ark to the saving of his house; by the which he condemned the world, and became heir of the righteousness which is by faith.” There was no thing in the discourse that could remain upon the memory, but it was among the best I have heard from this Gentleman— It is also probably the last, as his engagement here is now closed— After Church we had visits from Mr Fletcher and his Son. I walked before dinner round through Gunnersbury and Brentford— All the leisure of the day I was engaged upon my Journal.

Day. I have risen usually about six in the Morning; several times, an hour earlier, and occasionally an hour later; but always before daylight— I heard George read six Chapters in the French Bible, every morning, until his illness obliged me to dispense with his reading, first at that time of the day; and now altogether— Since then, I have been invariably occupied every morning until breakfast time upon this Journal, the arrears of which I have at length brought up within less than a week— We Breakfast about ten O’Clock, after which, when I do not go to London, my wife writes Letters for me, at my dictation, till three or four— I walk an hour and a half, at the dusk of Evening— Then write half an hour again upon my Journal till dinner at Six— After which until ten, my wife reads to me books of amusement, or we sit in conversation by the fire-side. About twice a week I go to Office in London, to dispatch any business requiring my presence; and on Sundays attend the Morning Service at Ealing Church. This varies the occupations only of the hours between breakfast and dinner— My eyes and hand are yet weak, but I hope recovering.

The close of the Year, is to be noted with fervent gratitude to the Giver of all good gifts, for the favours of all my life, and especially of the year— It has been remarkable, by my removal to England, and by the reunion of all my family around me— May the blessing of God, be granted to the results of both these Events!
